articles.title: HDAT9800 Chapter 1
articles.description: Chapter 1 material for HDAT9800 Visualisation & Communication of Health Data
articles.contents:
Contents
What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
Pre-recorded lectures
for Chapter 1
Tutorials for Chapter 1
Introduction to
R Tutorials for Beginners
Who
should complete the Introduction to R modules?


Interactive sessions
for Chapter 1
Further
instructions for the hands-on session

Chapter 1 assessment
exercise
Requesting early
marking

Readings and
Resources for Chapter 1




Graphic by Alison
Horst, used under CC-BY license.
What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
This chapter provides a course overview, including course aims and
principles, as well as a brief review of the history of data
visualisation (Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 1). It also provides
an introduction to the core curriculum material for each of the chapter
topics including an introduction to R, dplyr, literate programming, git,
ggplot2, collaborating with git, using leaflet for mapping, using shiny
for interactive applications, and the shiny group project (Chapter 1 -
Course Overview - Part 2).
There is also an introduction to using git for version control
(Chapter 1 - Version control with git and GitHub - Part 1), and how to
set up and configure git with RStudio, how to access the assessment
repository and the chapter 1 assessment (Chapter 1 - Version control
with git and GitHub - Part 2).
View the lecture videos, and download the lecture notes if you want
to follow along with the presenter (or for revision later).
After you have viewed the lectures, please proceed to do the
learnr tutorials on git.
There is also an interactive learnr tutorial covering
data manipulation using dplyr in R. This is also
foundational material for later chapters, which will require the use of
dplyr and related packages to manipulate and shape data for
visualisation and reporting.
The interactive tutorial session for Chapter 1 will start with a
get-to-know-you session, in which we each introduce ourselves, and talk
about our favourite data visualisation or chart (see below). There will
be an opportunity for questions and answers (Q&A) about the core
course material, and then a hands-on session in which we use the
dplyr package in R to access and manipulate data in
databases, along with a discussion of some fundamental concepts of
computer architecture and operations which are important to understand
when working with “big data”.
Links and further instructions for each component are provided in the
sections below.
Pre-recorded lectures for
Chapter 1
View the lecture videos below, and download the lecture notes if you
want to follow along with the presenter (or for revision later).
After you have viewed the lectures, please proceed to do the related
git tutorials (see below).
Course overview including course aims and principles
(Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 1)







Introduction of chapter topics including R,
dplyr, literate programming, git,
ggplot2, collaborating with git,
leaflet, shiny and the shiny group project
(Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 2)







Slide deck
for Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Parts 1 & 2
Using git for version control (Chapter 1 -
Version control with git and GitHub - Part
1)







Setting up and configuring git, setting up
git with RStudio, how to access the assessment
repository and the chapter 1 assessment (Chapter 1 - Version control
with git and GitHub - Part 2)







Slide deck for
Chapter 1 - git and GitHub - Parts 1 & 2
Tutorials for Chapter 1
Every chapter includes one or more interactive tutorials/practicals,
which consists of introductory concepts, readings and exercises,
generally provided as an R package of learnr tutorials.
learnr is a package which allows interactive tutorials
about R (or related topics) to be written in
R.
You should download and install the cbdrhintro tutorials
package for R by following the instructions provided on the
home page. Instructions for installing R and
RStudio are provided here.
The Chapter 1 tutorials have three parts:
Introduction to R tutorials (proficient R
users can quickly run through or skip these tutorials, see the more
detailed description of these tutorials below)
Introduction to git and GitHub
Introduction to dplyr
Please work through the content in the tutorials after you have
watched the pre-recorded lecture for this chapter.
If you have any questions about the tutorials, or if you want to
share any useful resources or post insights, please post in the Teams
space for the course, in the channel for Chapter 1.
Introduction to R
Tutorials for Beginners
R is fast becoming the industry standard programming
language for statistical data analysis. If this is your first exposure
to R, we have created some beginner R modules
to introduce you to the R language and to help you build
some basic programming skills.
The modules are delivered as 6 learnr tutorials as a
R package called cbdrhintro. Each module
consists of explanatory text and coding examples. The tutorials are
interactive so you can write and run code to see how it works, then
check your code against the provided solutions. The coding tasks in
these tutorial modules are not marked assessments, so don’t worry if you
make mistakes. Each module is organised into several subtopics, which
are bookmarked making it easy to pause and return at a later time.
Module 1: Introduction to R, variable types and operators
Module 2: Vectors
Module 3: Matrices, matrix arithmetic and lists
Module 4: Data frames and Factors
Module 5: Functions
Module 6: Control structures and control-like structures
Who should
complete the Introduction to R modules?
R programming is a major component of many of the UNSW
Health Data Science courses. Some of the R dependent
courses will include these same learnr tutorials as part of
the course content. If you have already worked through them, there is no
need to do them again (unless you wish to for revision purposes).
However if you are completely new to programming or new to
R, we recommend spending some time reviewing and practising
the lessons of these modules during the first few weeks of the HDAT9800
course.
For some students, this will be a lot of material to cover. Don’t
panic! The course (and the assessment due dates) are paced so that there
is plenty of time to get to grips with the fundamentals of
R programming. If you would like additional interactive
tutorials covering the Introduction to R material or the opportunity to
ask questions about it individually or in small groups, please let me
know on Teams or at timothy.churches@unsw.edu.au.
Please follow the instructions for installing the
cbdrhintro tutorials package for R on the course home page and proceed to do the
dplyr tutorial. We will revisit and revise the use of
dply in the interactive session, and examine how it can be
used to access “big data” contained in databases, in the context of
modern computing architecture and operation.
If you are unfamiliar with R, you should also work through the six
introduction to R tutorials that are also contained in and installed by
that package.
Interactive sessions for
Chapter 1

In the first interactive tutorial for the course, we will start off
with introductions. Your course instructors will introduce themselves
and then each student will be requested to briefly talk about themselves
(where you are from, what is your work/educational background, how much
experience you have had working with health or other data).
We would also like you to briefly present a data visualisation (by
someone else) that you have found interesting, or persuasive, or even
just beautiful. You only need to describe it for 30 seconds and tell us
what about it interests you. It does not need to be health-related.
Don’t spend too much time looking for something, it is not a marked
exercise, and if you don’t have time to find something for this week,
don’t worry, we can show the visualisation you chose in later weeks. Be
ready to show it on your computer screen. We will create a page on the
course web site to feature each of these as a lasting record.
After these introductions, there will be an opportunity to ask
questions about the course, the assessments and the content for Chapter
1. We will repeat this every week, and you can ask questions about
earlier chapters at any time, of course.
Please note: Although a working knowledge of SQL is a valuable, or
perhaps even an essential skill, for most data scientists, you are
not expected to acquire such skills as part of this
course, and none of the assessments require knowledge or understanding
of SQL.
Then we will cover some additional material: there will be a brief
talk by Tim Churches on computer architecture, databases and big data,
and then we will work through a hands-on exercise using the ‘dplyr’ and
‘dbplyr’ packages for R to access data in an SQL database.
However, some links to introductory resources on SQL will be added to
this page in the near future for your future reference, given that SQL
and databases is not currently covered in any of the other HDAT
courses.
You need to bring (or be using) your laptop, have R and RStudio
installed, and have the dplyr package installed (or better,
the entire tidyverse meta-package).
Further
instructions for the hands-on session
In the hands-on session, we will be running the following code in
this gist. Don’t run it yet! You will need to create a new
project in RStudio, access the code in the gist and
coy-and-paste it into a new R code window in RStudio. We will then step
through it section by section.
Code
gist for Chapter 1 hands-on session
The HTML slide deck which was made using the Xaringan package for R
was rendered to PDF using the method documented here.
The slide deck in HTML (web) format for the session can be accessed

here (or as a

PDF).
Chapter 1 assessment
exercise
For chapter 1, the assessment exercise is very easy, and is designed
to get you used to completing assessments using git and
GitHub.
Make sure you have installed git on your computer and
that you have a GitHub account, as explained in the
pre-recorded lectures and tutorials on git (see above), and
that git is configured in RStudio.
Then you can click on this link to the Chapter 1 assessment GitHub
Classroom repository: https://classroom.github.com/a/4J9wKhgK
This will create a new GitHub repository for you, just for this
assignment. Only you and the course instructors can access it, it is not
public.
You should then clone this assignment repository to your local
computer, using RStudio (or other git interfaces such as GitHub Desktop
if you prefer). Complete the assignment (assessment task) according to
the instructions given, save and commit your work to your local git
repository, and then push that work back to the remote
GitHub repository for the assessment (this should all be
automatically set up when you clone the repo in RStudio).
You may revise your assessment task(s) as many times as you wish. We
will mark the last committed version that you push to the GitHub
repository for your chapter assessment by the due date.
Requesting early marking
You may request early marking of your submitted assessment by
following the steps outlined here.
Readings and Resources for
Chapter 1


Core readings


Jennifer Bryan (2018) Excuse Me, Do You Have a Moment to Talk About
Version Control?, The American Statistician, 72:1, 20-27





Other resources


An excellent presentation on git and GitHub by Dr Mark Hanly, with a set
of exercises on using git on the command line starting at slide 40 (HTML
and PDF versions)






Tutorial provided by RStudio on using dplyr with external databases






You should prioritise the core readings each week.

articles.title: HDAT9800 Chapter 2
articles.description: Chapter 2 material for HDAT9800 Visualisation & Communication of Health Data
articles.contents:
Contents
Introduction
to the core curriculum content for this chapter (Dr James
Farrow)
What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
Pre-recorded lectures
for Chapter 2
learnr
tutorial for Chapter 2
Optional
practical exercises (not assessed or marked)

Interactive sessions
for Chapter 2
Solving problems with
GitHub access

Chapter 2 assessment
exercise
Requesting early
marking

Readings and
Resources for Chapter 2




Graphic by Alison
Horst, used under CC-BY license.
Introduction
to the core curriculum content for this chapter (Dr James Farrow)







What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
Part 1
An overview of literate programming
Introduction to literate programming in the R ecosystem: R markdown
and knitr

Part 2
a quick look at some additional output formats for knitr

View the lecture videos (below), and download the lecture notes
(available for Part A only, there is no slide deck for part B) if you
want to follow along with the presenter (or for revision later).
There is also an interactive learnr tutorial covering
literate programming using knitr. This covers much of the
same material as the Part 1 lecture for Chapter 2, but goes into a bit
more detail.
Links and further instructions for each component are provided in the
sections below.
Pre-recorded lectures for
Chapter 2
View the lecture videos below, and download the lecture notes if you
want to follow along with the presenter (or for revision later).
Part 1







Slide
deck for Chapter 2 - Part 1
Part 2







There is no slide deck for Part 2.*
After you have viewed the lectures, please proceed to do the related
knitr tutorial (see below).
learnr tutorial for
Chapter 2
You should download and install the hdat9800 tutorials
package for R by following the instructions provided on the
home page. Instructions for installing R and
RStudio are provided here.
**Note*: Essentially the same tutorial is contained in the
cbdrhintro tutorials package. However, you should do the
one called “Chapter 2: knitr” because it is slightly
more up-to-date. We will endeavour to fix this duplication of tutorials
in the near future. However, it doesn’t really matter which version of
the knitr tutorial you do.
The tutorial is also available online via the link from the course
schedule table on the course home page.
The tutorial covers much of the same material as in the pre-recorded
lectures, but goes into a bit more detail. See below for suggested
practical exercises to be undertaken after you have finished reviewing
the tutorial.
If you have any questions about the lectures or tutorials, or if you
want to share any useful resources or post insights, please post in the
Teams
space for the course, in the channel for Chapter 2.
Optional
practical exercises (not assessed or marked)
Practice creating some R markdown documents of different types
(reports, presentations), add your own text, images and R code (any code
you wish), and render (knit) them in different formats (HTML, PDF) and
compare how they are rendered and behave.
Install the rticles package in RStudio, and use it
to create an R markdown manuscript document for one of the scholarly
journals it supports (PLOS One or ArXiv are good choices).
If you wish, post examples of your rendered (knitted) documents as
HTML or PDF files attached to The Chapter 2 channel in the course teams
space.
Interactive sessions for
Chapter 2

The Chapter 2 interactive sessions (online Wednesday at 6pm,
face-to-face Thursday at 2pm) will cover the following topics:
Q&A on Chapter 2 (and Chapter 1) curriculum material
discussion of the core readings for this week (see below, please
reading them before the section if possible, but we will be briefly
recapping the main points)
a hands-on workshop on creating your own health data science blog
site using the Distill literate programming framework for
R, Rmarkdown and knitr.
For the hands-on workshop, you will need your laptop with
R and RStudio installed, and access to your
GitHub account. The distill package for R (and its
dependencies, which will automatically be installed too) will be needed.
If possible, you should install that before the session.
The session will not go as long as the Chapter 1 session, and we will
take a break for 5 minutes every hour!
The slide deck in HTML (web) format for the session can be accessed

here (or as a

PDF).
There is an additional video which illustrates each of the steps in
creating a blog site:







Solving problems with
GitHub access
When attempting to set up a blog site on GitHub, you may encounter
errors relating to authenticating to GitHub. This is because GitHub now
requires the use of PATs (personal access tokens) to
authenticate to repositories, rather than passwords (you still need your
GitHub account password to access the GitHub website, so don’t lose
that!). A PAT only needs to be set up once in RStudio to enable you to
use the git and GitHub tools built into RStudio. To do this, follow the
steps in sections 9.1, 9.3 and 9.4 of (this guide by Jenny Bryan)[https://happygitwithr.com/https-pat.html]. Section 9.2
contains additional details about HTTPS vs SSH authentication which you
don’t need to detail with – just use HTTPS. If you need additional help,
please contact the course instructors via email or Teams, we are very
happy to help.
Chapter 2 assessment
exercise
For Chapter 2, the assessment exercise is slightly more involved than
Chapter 1, and is intended to give you some practice editing Rmarkdown
documents. Access the assessment the same way as for Chapter 1, by
clicking on this link to the Chapter 2 assessment GitHub Classroom
repository: https://classroom.github.com/a/tOV9OQvh
Note: Please ignore the mention of the creation of a
Xaringan presentation as an additional assessment task, right at the end
of the in the pre-recorded lecture for Chapter 2, This will create a new
GitHub repository for you, just for this assignment. Only you and the
course instructors can access it, it is not public.
You should then clone this assignment repository to your local
computer, using RStudio (or other git interfaces such as GitHub Desktop
if you prefer). Complete the assignment (assessment task) according to
the instructions given, save and commit your work to your local git
repository, and then push that work back to the remote
GitHub repository for the assessment (this should all be
automatically set up when you clone the repo in RStudio).
Be sure that you can successfully knit the Rmd
(R markdown) document that you will be working on in those assessment,
before you commit and push your final version. The instructors will be
marking your Rmd file by re-rendering it (re-knitting
it).
You may revise your assessment task(s) as many times as you wish. We
will mark the last committed version that you push to the GitHub
repository for your chapter assessment by the due date.
Requesting early marking
You may request early marking of your submitted assessment by
following the steps outlined here.
Readings and Resources for
Chapter 2


Core readings


Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 1 -
Introduction





Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 2 - Mapping
data onto aesthetics





Other resources


RStudio Inc. Cheat Sheets (available directly in RStudio)





Xie Y. 15 Tips on Making Better Use of R Markdown. RStudio, 2019. (Yihui
Xie is the creator of knitr for R and has a great sense of humour…)





Cullen B., Hill A., Velasquez I. R Markdown Lesser-Known Tips &
Tricks #2: Cleaning Up Your Code. RStudio blog post, 6 Jan 2022.





McNulty K. Ten awesome R Markdown tricks. Towards Data Science (blog), 9
Dec 2022.






You should prioritise the core readings each week.

articles.title: HDAT9800 Chapter 3
articles.description: Chapter 3 material for HDAT9800 Visualisation & Communication of Health Data
articles.contents:
Contents
Introduction
to the core curriculum content for this chapter (Dr James
Farrow)
What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
Pre-recorded lecture
for Chapter 3
learnr
tutorial for Chapter 3
Interactive sessions
for Chapter 3
Chapter 3 assessment
exercise
Requesting early
marking

Readings and
Resources for Chapter 3




Graphic by Alison
Horst, used under CC-BY license.
Introduction
to the core curriculum content for this chapter (Dr James Farrow)







What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
The pre-recorded lecture covers:
pragmatic focus on how to create data visualisations in R
with a little bit of underlying theory
quick overview of the base R graphics and
lattice graphics systems
then focus on ggplot2
in subsequent chapters we’ll look at add-ons and extensions to the
ggplot2 framework
as well as a bit more theory on good visualisation practice

After viewing the pre-recorded lecture below (the slide deck for it
is available below the video), you should go through the interactive
learnr tutorial available from the Tutorial page for this chapter.
There is just one learnr tutorial for Chapter 3 covering
the use of the ggplot2 library for R. This covers much of
the same material as the lecture for Chapter 3, but in a lot more
detail, and includes a worked example of a statistical analysis of a
dataset facilitated by visualisation using ggplot2.
Links and further instructions for each component are provided in the
sections below.
Pre-recorded lecture for
Chapter 3
View the lecture video below, and download the lecture notes
(separated into part A and part B if you want to follow along with the
presenter (or for revision later).







Slide
deck for Chapter 3 - part A
Slide
deck for Chapter 3 - part B
After you have viewed the lecture, please proceed to do the related
ggplot2 tutorial (see below).
learnr tutorial for
Chapter 3
You should download and install the hdat9800 tutorials
package for R by following the instructions provided on the
home page. Instructions for installing R and
RStudio are provided here.
The tutorial is also available online via the link from the course
schedule table on the course home page.
The tutorial covers much of the same ggplot2 material as
in the pre-recorded lecture, but goes into quite a lot more detail.
If you have any questions about the lectures or tutorials, or if you
want to share any useful resources or post insights, please post in the
Teams
space for the course, in the channel for Chapter 3.
Interactive sessions for
Chapter 3
The Chapter 3 interactive sessions (online Wednesday at 6pm,
face-to-face Thursday at 2pm) will cover the following topics:
Q&A on Chapter 2 (and previous chapters) curriculum
material
discussion of the core readings for this week (see below, please
reading them before the section if possible, but we will be briefly
recapping the main points)
a hands-on workshop on exploring aspects of the ggplot2
package
For the hands-on workshop, you will need your laptop with
R and RStudio installed You need to have
installed the dplyr and ggplot2 packages. The
easiest way to do that is to just install the tidyverse
meta-package, if you have not already done so. We’ll be installing a few
other packages during the session.
Please DO NOT look at the slide deck before the
session!
The slide deck in HTML (web) format for the session can be accessed

here (or as a

PDF).
Chapter 3 assessment
exercise
For Chapter 3, the assessment exercise is intended to give you some
practice modifying R code to create specific visualisations using the
ggplot2 package, and embedding that code in an Rmarkdown
documents. The framework for the Rmarkdown document you will be
completing is supplied, and the coding tasks should be fairly
straightforward if you have worked through the pre-recorded lecture and
the learnr tutorial for Chapter 3. Access the assessment
the same way as for previous chapters, by clicking on this link to the
Chapter 3 assessment GitHub Classroom repository: https://classroom.github.com/a/QqP0VEjV
This will create a new GitHub repository for you, just for this
assignment. Only you and the course instructors can access it, it is not
public.
You should then clone this assignment repository to your local
computer, using RStudio (or other git interfaces such as GitHub Desktop
if you prefer). Complete the assignment (assessment task) according to
the instructions given, save and commit your work to your local git
repository, and then push that work back to the remote
GitHub repository for the assessment (this should all be
automatically set up when you clone the repo in RStudio).
Be sure that you can successfully knit the Rmd
(R markdown) document that you will be working on in those assessment,
before you commit and push your final version. The instructors will be
marking your Rmd file by re-rendering it (re-knitting
it).
You may revise your assessment task(s) as many times as you wish. We
will mark the last committed version that you push to the GitHub
repository for your chapter assessment by the due date.
Requesting early marking
You may request early marking of your submitted assessment by
following the steps outlined here.
Readings and Resources for
Chapter 3


Core readings


Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 3 -
Coordinate systems and axes





Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 4 - Colour
scales





Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 5 -
Directory of visualisations





Other resources


ggplot2 reference web site





Wickham H, Navarro D, Pedersen TL. ggplot2: elegant graphics for data
analsysis. Springer, 2016 ISBN-13: 978-3319242750 (available for free
online)





Chang W. R Graphics Cookbook. O’Reilly, 2019. (available online for
free)





ggplot2 extensions gallery






You should prioritise the core readings each week.

articles.title: HDAT9800 Chapter 4
articles.description: Chapter 4 material for HDAT9800 Visualisation & Communication of Health Data
articles.contents:
Contents
Introduction
to the core curriculum content for this chapter (Dr James
Farrow)
What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
learnr
tutorial for Chapter 4
Interactive sessions
for Chapter 4
Chapter 4 assessment
exercise
Requesting early
marking

Readings and
Resources for Chapter 4




Graphic by Alison
Horst, used under CC-BY license.
Introduction
to the core curriculum content for this chapter (Dr James Farrow)







What’s in
the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
The pre-recorded lecture covers:
Working as a group
Tools for collaboration
Practices for collaboration
Resolving edit conflicts using git
Examples of conflict and resolution
After viewing the pre-recorded lecture below (the slide deck for it
is available below the video), you should go through the interactive
learnr tutorial for this chapter (see below).







Slide deck
for Chapter 4
After you have viewed the lecture, please proceed to do the related
conflicts in git tutorial (see below).
learnr tutorial for
Chapter 4
You should download and re-install the hdat9800
tutorials package for R by following the instructions
provided on the home page. Instructions for installing R
and RStudio are provided here.
The tutorial for this chapter is also available online via the link
from the course schedule table on the course home page.
The tutorial covers much of the same material as in the pre-recorded
lecture, but goes into quite a lot more detail.
If you have any questions about the lectures or tutorials, or if you
want to share any useful resources or post insights, please post in the
Teams
space for the course, in the channel for Chapter 4.
Interactive sessions for
Chapter 4
The Chapter 4 interactive sessions (online Wednesday at 6pm,
face-to-face Thursday at 2pm) will cover the following topics:
guest presentation by Dr Georgina Kennedy on data visualisation in
python
Q&A on Chapter 3 (and previous chapters) curriculum
material
if we have time (otherwise carried-over to week 5):
discussion/recap of the core readings for this week (see below,
please reading them before the section if possible, but we will be
briefly recapping the main points)
a hands-on workshop on exploring more aspects of the
ggplot2 package

For the hands-on workshop (if we have time), you will need your
laptop with R and RStudio installed You need
to have installed the dplyr and ggplot2
packages. The easiest way to do that is to just install the
tidyverse meta-package, if you have not already done so.
We’ll be installing a few other packages during the session.
There is no slide deck for the textbook readings and
ggplot2 exercise this week, but there will be one for next
week including this weeks readings.
The slide deck for Dr Georgie Kennedy’s talk on data viz in python
will be posted here on Thurs afternoon 23 June.
Chapter 4 assessment
exercise
For Chapter 4, the assessment exercise is intended to check your
understanding of the material covered in the Chpater 4 pre-recorded
lecture. The framework for the Rmarkdown document you will be completing
is supplied, and you just need to fill in your answers as text. Access
the assessment the same way as for previous chapters, by clicking on
this link to the Chapter 4 assessment GitHub Classroom repository: https://classroom.github.com/a/Tu9O8IFj
This will create a new GitHub repository for you, just for this
assignment. Only you and the course instructors can access it, it is not
public.
You should then clone this assignment repository to your local
computer, using RStudio (or other git interfaces such as GitHub Desktop
if you prefer). Complete the assignment (assessment task) according to
the instructions given, save and commit your work to your local git
repository, and then push that work back to the remote
GitHub repository for the assessment (this should all be
automatically set up when you clone the repo in RStudio).
Be sure that you can successfully knit the Rmd
(R markdown) document that you will be working on in those assessment,
before you commit and push your final version. The instructors will be
marking your Rmd file by re-rendering it (re-knitting
it).
You may revise your assessment task(s) as many times as you wish. We
will mark the last committed version that you push to the GitHub
repository for your chapter assessment by the due date.
Requesting early marking
You may request early marking of your submitted assessment by
following the steps outlined here.
Readings and Resources for
Chapter 4


Core readings


Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 6 -
Visualising amounts





Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. Chapter 7 -
Visualising distributions





Other resources


Scott Chacon, Ben Straub. Pro Git. APress, 2014. Chapter 3.1 Branches in
a nutshell






You should prioritise the core readings each week.

articles.title: Contact us
articles.contents:
Contents
Questions and
discussion
Your lecturers
Errors or omissions
on this website

Questions and discussion
Class or assessment related questions can be posted to Assessments
channel in the course Teams space here.
Your lecturers
Dr Tim Churches
Senior Research Fellow and Course Convenor
School of Clinical Medicine, Faculty of Medicine & Health, UNSW
Sydney
E: timothy.churches@unsw.edu.au
Dr Dami Sotade Research Officer Centre for Big Data Research in
Health, Faculty of Medicine & Health, UNSW Sydney E: o.sotade@unsw.edu.au


Errors or omissions on this
website
This website was built using Distill for R
Markdown. The source code is available online at https://github.com/CBDRH-HDAT9800/cbdrh-hdat9800.github.io.
Errors or omissions on this website can be logged using GitHub issues here.

articles.title: Favourite visualisations
articles.contents:
Contents
Favourite visualisations
Tim Churches
Melvin Galera
Ivana Deng
Katy Liu


Favourite visualisations
This page is a work-in-progress. More examples will be added in due
course.
In no particular order.
Tim Churches
From one of Edward Tufte’s amazing series of books in data
visualisation, in this case Beautiful Evidence..
Beautful Evidence…the page in which he introduces teh idea of sparklines,
which are very small charts, stripped of all but the most releveant
information and detail, which can be embedded in text (and tables). We
will examone the use of sparklines later in this course.
Beautful EvidenceMelvin Galera
The now-famous Johns Hopkins COVID-19 map site, that became a major
source of COVID updates in 202 and 2021. A great example of a health
information dashboard, in this case built using the commercial ESRI GIS
(geographic information system) software platform.
Johns Hopkins COVID-19
Dashboard

Ivana Deng
A World Bank project using unsupervised ML (machine learning)
clustering of topics in large numbers of project reports. This methods
finds emergent topic clusters in high dimensions. In order to visualise
these, the high number of dimensions needs to be flattened using a
technique called t-SNE, which we will examine briefly in this
course.
The full World Bank report containing this image can be accessed here.
t-SNE flattening
Katy Liu
A great visualisation of teh size and impact of communicable disease
pandemics through the ages. Click on the image below to be taken to the
web page with the full visualisation.

articles.title: HDAT9800 Health Data Visualisation and Communication
articles.description:
The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see.
-- John Tukey
articles.contents:
Contents
About the HDAT9800
course
Course Schedule Term 2
2022
Teams Space
Weekly interactive
tutorials
The tutorials R
packages
Assessments
Weekly core curriculum
assessments
Requesting early
marking

Additional assessments
Group assessment
Assessment exercises
timetable

Readings and resources
Course Textbook
Other resources





About the HDAT9800 course
Health Data Scientists need to present information to audiences
across a range of backgrounds and spanning a spectrum from naïve or
non-practitioners of a discipline to highly informed and expert
audiences. Effective communication across different media types is
essential. Appropriate data visualisation techniques can greatly enhance
communication and increase the effectiveness of communication. Data
visualisation is an essential part of every data analysis. Increasingly
the scientific community has become aware of problems regarding lack of
transparency and reproducibility, and the use of fully reproducible
methods of working are now essential.
This course takes a toolbox approach to creating appropriate,
reproducible and transparent analyses and visualisations, and
communicating them via various channels and modes, including informal
and formal written communication, online communication and via
interactive applications. In the context of R, it presents useful
best-practice data science analysis and visualisation techniques with a
focus on different types of data visualisations.
This course was originally developed in 2018 by Dr James Farrow and
Dr Tim Churches. It was co-presented by James and Tim in 2018 and 2019,
and co-presented by James and Tim in entirely online form in 2020, and
by Tim and Andy Blance in 2021. Although the core material for the
course remains substantially unchanged, a great deal of additional
material was added in 2021, and for 2022 some further topics will be
covered.
The original course introduction recorded by Dr James Farrow appears
below, and is still valid - we have not removed anything from the core
curriculum, although quite a lot of the material has been updated or
supplemented to reflect recent developments. The additional material
added in 2021 and 2022 will be covered in the interactive sessions on
Thursday afternoons/evenings in the Term 2 2022 running of the
course.







Course Schedule Term 2 2022

Links to slides and recordings will be posted on the page for each
(weekly) chapter throughout the course.
For Term 2 2022, the course is provided in both blended (hybrid) and
online formats. Each Chapter, which corresponds to a week in the ten
week course, comprises pre-recorded lectures, interactive tutorials
which student work through themselves, and a weekly interactive tutorial
session. These tutorial sessions are provided in both online and
face-to-face form (on the UNSW Kensington campus).
There is a web page for each chapter (week) of the course, setting
out exactly what you need to do each week (see links in the Course
Schedule table below).


Week


Week starting


Core topic(s)


Additional topic(s)


learnr tutorial


Online Tutorial


Face-to-Face Tutorial


Chapter web page


Tutorial recordings


Week 1


Mon 30 May


Course Introduction; What is Data Visualisation; Introduction to R;
Introduction to git


Introductions; dplyr and the R tidyverse; computer architecture,
databases, SQL and accessing databases from R; hands-on exercise





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 1 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 2 Jun








Week 2


Mon 06 June


Introduction to Literate Programming


Communication by self-publishing; hands-on setting up your own health
data science blog





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 8 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 9 Jun








Week 3


Mon 13 June


Constructing Charts using ggplot2


Some more visualisation theory; more on data visualisation using ggplot2





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 15 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 16 Jun








Week 4


Mon 20 June


Collaborative Report Writing (including tables)


Visualisation with Python – guest tutorial by Dr Georgina Kennedy





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 22 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 23 Jun








Week 5


Mon 27 June


Visualisation and Mapping part 1


Theories of Visual Perception – guest tutorial by Andy Blance; a
visualisation I am proud of (Dr Malcolm Gillies)





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 29 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 30 Jun








Week 6


Mon 04 July


Building Interactive Data-driven Web Apps using Shiny part 1


Guest lecture by Prof Louisa Jorm on communicating with non-technical
audiences; Visualisation and exploratory data analysis; visualisation of
statistical models





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 6 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 7 Jul








Week 7


Mon 11 July


Visualisation and Mapping part 2


Incorporating time – uses and misuses of animation in data
visualisation; accessibility aspects of visualisation





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 13 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 14 Jul








Week 8


Mon 18 July


Building Interactive Data-driven Web Apps using Shiny part 2


Visualisation of categorical data; visualising big data; a visualisation
I am proud of (guest presentation)





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 20 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 21 Jul








Week 9


Mon 25 July


Building Interactive Data-driven Web Apps using Shiny part 3


Communicating COVID-19 models through Markdown documents, web sites,
pre-print papers and Shiny apps – guest presentation by Dr Mark Hanly





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 27 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 28 Jul








Week 10


Mon 01 August


Course Review and Group Project Presentations


Visualising higher dimensions – uses and misuses of 3D graphics;
dimensionality reduction techniques, including a guest presentation by
Dr Nic Kuo on t-SNE dimensionality reduction for visualising NLP models





6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 3 Aug


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 4 Aug









Teams Space
Discussions, questions and online tutorials will be hosted in the
course Teams Space which you can access here.

Weekly interactive tutorials
A weekly interactive tutorial session is offered, in both online and
face-to-face formats. The material covered in both formats is identical.
Each tutorial starts with a question-and-answer sessions on the core
curriculum material for that and previous weeks, and then goes on to
cover additional material, usually a mixture of short lectures or
presentations and a hands-on practical exercise. Some weeks feature a
guest presenter (see details in the course schedule table below and on
each course chapter page).
Attendance at tutorial sessions is optional but strongly encouraged.
However, we recognise that some students may not be able to attend
either the online or the face-to-face sessions due to work, family or
other commitments. For those students, the online sessions will be
recorded and available the next day for viewing at their
convenience.

International students who have enrolled in the course for
blended/hybrid delivery and who are on a student visa,
are required to attend at least 3 hours per week of
face-to-face classes on campus for each course to meet your visa
requirements. Such students should make every effort to attend the
face-to-face classes. If you are such a student, but you can’t make it
to one of the face-to-face sessions, please just let me know by email at
timothy.churches@unsw.edu.au so I can keep a record of
why.
The online interactive tutorials will be held using Teams at 6pm
(Sydney time) each Wednesday. The tutorial will usually last between 2
and 2.5 hours. You can join the tutorials using this
link. These tutorials should also appear in your Teams calendar.
The face-to-face interactive tutorials will be held on the UNSW
Kensington campus in the Mathews 104 room (K-F23-104) starting at 2pm
each Thursday. These tutorials will also usually last between 2 and 2.5
hours. It may not be possible for all guest presenters to attend these
tutorials in person, in which case the presentations may be provided
online or students may view the recorded online tutorial for those parts
of the tutorial. Please bring your laptop to these tutorials.
The tutorials R packages
Online, hosted versions of the learnr tutorials for this
course can be accessed through the links in the Course Schedule table
above, but it is better to use a local copy that you can work on in the
RStudio environment without the need for internet access.
You will need a copy of R and RStudio running on your computer in order
to participate in the interactive (face-to-face or online) tutorial
sessions held each Thursday, and to complete and submit assignments.
If you do not already have R and RStudio installed, please follow the
instructions on the Installing R page.
If you have any problems or questions please contact the course convenor
Tim Churches on teams of by email at timothy.churches@unsw.edu.au.
Once installed, the tutorials can be accessed via the
Tutorial tab in the upper right-hand pane of the
RStudio application window.
The tutorials for Chapter 1 are shipped in the package
cbdrhintro. To install this package you can enter the
following code at the console:


devtools::install_github("CBDRH/cbdrhintro")



You may get prompted to update some packages. You can chose to ignore
this by selecting option 3 (None).

If you choose to update packages, you may subsequently be asked if
you want to install binary or source versions. Source versions require
special tools to compile which you may not have configured, so you
should choose to install the binary version, i.e. if prompted Do you
want to install from sources the packages which need compilation?
enter n for ‘No’.
The package installation can occasionally fail, usually if there is a
dependency that is not installed or has an outdated version. If you get
an error message relating to a package, try installing that package
first and then try again. If there are still issues, don’t worry, just
drop an email to the course convenor.
Please note: if you have installed the
cbdrhintro previously, you will need to re-install it again
because we have added a tutorial for dplyr required for
Chapter 1 of this course.
The tutorials for Chapters 2 onwards are shipped in the package
hdat9800tutorials. To install this package you can enter
the following code at the console:


devtools::install_github("CBDRH/hdat9800")



You may need to re-install this package from time to time as
instructed to receive updates to the tutorials.

Back to the top


Assessments
Weekly core curriculum
assessments
There are weekly individual assessments for Chapters 1 to 7. Each of
these assessments is worth 8% of the total marks for the course, thus
56% all together. These weekly assessments cover the core course
material and should be fairly easy and will not take very long to
complete if you have worked through the core curriculum material. The
weekly assessments must be submitted for marking no later than three
weeks after the opening date for the chapter they relate to – the exact
dates for each are shown in the table below. However, you are encouraged
to submit the core curriculum assignments early, if possible, to allow
more time for the additional assignments (see below). The course
instructors will endeavour to mark and return assignments submitted
before the due date as quickly as possible, so that you can get feedback
and assurance on your progress and understanding of the course
material.
Requesting early marking
You may request early marking of your submitted core curriculum
assessments by following the steps outlined here.
Additional assessments
There are also two additional assignments. These relate to topics
covered in the Thursday tutorial sessions, but require additional
independent research and some creativity to complete. Each is worth 7%
of the total course marks, thus 14% all together. The exact dates on
which each these are due is also shown in the table below. These
assignments will be marked promptly after the due date for each.

In the 2021 running of this course we set these additional assessment
tasks every week. However, feedback from students was that the
assessment burden was too great and that they didn’t have time to do the
additional assessments justice. Therefore we have reduced the number of
these additional assessments to just two this year.
Group assessment
In week 6 of the course, you will be asked to form into small groups
of 3 or 4 students each, to undertake a group assessment task. More
details of this task will be provided in week 4 of the course. Each
group will be required to present their group project in the Thursday
sessions in week 10, and then submit all the code for the project in the
week following that. The group assessment is worth 30% of the overall
course marks.
Assessment exercises
timetable


Assessment


Weight


Due date


Repo link


Chapter 1 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 20 Jun





Chapter 2 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 27 Jun





Additional assessment A


7%

Chapter 3 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 4 Jul





Chapter 4 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 11 Jul





Chapter 5 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 18 Jul





Additional assessment B


7%


9am, Thur 4 Aug





Chapter 6 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 25 Jul





Chapter 7 assessment


8%


9am, Mon 1 Aug





Group assessment


30%


9am, Mon 7 Aug






Click the link to clone a personal copy of the GitHub repo for each
assessment. You will complete your assessment as an RMarkdown document,
pushing it back to GitHub when you are ready to submit.

Readings and resources
There are links to readings and additional resources on the page for
each chapter of the course. You should prioritise the core readings each
week.
Course Textbook

Claus O. Wilke. Fundamentals of Data Visualization. O’Reilly
Media, Sebastopol, CA. 2019. ISBN 978-1-492-03108-6.
This is a great introduction to data visualisation in the biological
and biomedical sciences (the author is a biologist). Furthermore, it
uses R throughout, and the entire text is itself written
using literate programming methods in R! Best of all, it is available
under a Creative Commons license and thus can be accessed and used
without cost. By all means buy the published version (I have a copy),
but you don’t have to – the full textbook can be accessed online. You can even
access the source code for it.
Starting with Chapter 2, there will be a set reading of part of the
text each week which we will discuss in the interactive sessions. Don’t
worry, the readings will not be very long.
Other resources
To be updated shortly.

articles.title: Installing R and RStudio
articles.description: Instructions for installing R and RStudio on your computer
articles.contents:
To participate in the HDAT9800 course you will need a copy of both
R and RStudio installed on your computer. Both
R and RStudio are free, open-source software
available at no cost and able to be installed on as many computers as
you wish at no charge.
R is a programming language and associated software
libraries designed for statistical and data science computing. It is the
“engine”, but provides only simple user interfaces. RStudio
is an IDE (integrated development environment) application designed
specifically for R although it works with other programming
languages such as Python. It provides a very convenient and easy-to-use
interface for working with R.
First download R (choose the installation package
appropriate for your computer’s operating system - Win/MacOS/Linux) from
CRAN (the Comprehensive R Archive Network, which distributes R software
worldwide via a series of mirror sites) at https://cloud.r-project.org.
Download the R package appropriate for your computer’s
operating system (Windows, Apple macOS or Linux) from the “Download and
Install R” section at the top of the CRAN distribution page. Locate the
downloaded package file in your downloads directory, and open it to run
it. Just use the default settings for the installation.
Next, download RStudio Desktop from https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/.
Select the free Open Source Edition. It should take you to this
page. Download the package appropriate for your computer’s operating
system (it should detect that and offer the correct package next to step
2. on the Rstudio downlaod page at https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download.
Locate the downloaded file in your Downloads folder, open it to initiate
the RStudio installation wizard.Again, just follow the installation
default options offered.
Open RStudio - when it opens it should automatically
detect and link to the R installation on your computer.
You can learn more about what’s available in RStudio Desktop here: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/#Desktop
You will also need to install and configure git on your
computer. This is covered in the tutorials on git and
GitHub available on the Chapter
1 page for the HDAT9800 course.

articles.title: HDAT9800 Request early marking for assessments
articles.description: Procedure to request early marking for submitted assessments
articles.contents:
For the Term 2 2022 running of the HDAT9800 course, we are offering
early marking of core assignments (those for Chapters 1 to 7). This
enables students to work at their own pace through the core curriculum
material and the corresponding assessments, potentially leaving more
time to work on the two additional assessments, the group assessment and
otherwise engage with the additional material offered in each
Chapter.
If you have completed a chapter assessment and submitted a final
version of your solution to git, and pushed that to your assessment repo
on GitHub (the repo that was automatically created for you when you
clicked on the assignment link), then you can request early marking
(before the assessment due date) by carrying out the steps listed below
(it only takes a few seconds).
Note: Requesting early marking is optional, and if
you don’t request it, we will mark your asessments anyway, but not until
after the due date for each assessment.
In your web browser, go to the repository for the assignment
(GitHub will have sent you an email with a link to it, but it will also
show up in your list of repositories if you log in to GitHub).
Click on the Issues tab (highlighted in red in example screenshot
below)

You should be at the issue page for the repo. Click on the
New Issue button.

This will open a new issue form. Fill it out as shown below in the
red highlighted ovals, with “Ready for marking” as the issue title, and
@timchurches @OSotade as the body of the issue (that will
make it show up in the course instructors open issues lists, see below).
When you have filled those in, click the Submit new
issue button as highlighted below.

You should see an open issue for your assessment repository that
looks like the screenshot below. That’s all you need to do!

The issue you just opened will show up in the open issues list in
GitHub for the course instructors (see below for an example). When your
assessment has been marked, the instructors will close the issue with a
comment that the assessment has been marked. You should receive an email
notification about that automatically from GitHub.
This workflow is exactly what you would use if working with
collaborators via git and GitHub – for example, on your group Assessment
for this course!

Note: Please don’t share your marks or comments on
your marked assignment with fellow students until after
the submission deadline for that assessment.
